2.1 Setup
Let us briefly explore the std.lang transpiler.
Stdlang can be used in different ways: - generate code for different languages - run the code in different runtimes of those languages
To specify a way to use it, we use l/script.
For example, let us define the following two ways, named :code and :node.
Here we define :code as a way to use the transpiler to generate Javascript code, but not use it in any runtime.
Here we define :node as a way to use the transpiler go generate Javascript code, and run it in a Node.js runtime.
Let us now use these two ways for basic arithmetic.

(ns stdlang-book.walkthrough
  (:require [std.lang :as l]
            [scicloj.kindly.v4.kind :as kind]
            [scicloj.kindly.v4.api :as kindly]
            [charred.api :as charred]
            [clojure.string :as str]))






^:kind/println ; just so the return value of this call is displayed nicely
(l/script+ [:code :js])


[#rt:lang[:js]]



^:kind/println
(l/script+ [:node :js]
           {:runtime :basic})


[#rt.basic[:server/basic :js urp4zq42sdo4 45493 1]]



[;; No runtime, just generating code:
 (l/! [:code] (+ 1 2))
 ;; Generating, running in Node.js:
 (l/! [:node] (+ 1 2))]


["1 + 2;" 3]

2.3 Data visualization with Javascript

(kind/hiccup
 [:div
  [:script
   (l/! [:code]
        (do (var m (L.map document.currentScript.parentElement))
            (m.setView [-37.84 144.95]
                       11)
            (-> (L.tileLayer.provider "OpenStreetMap.Mapnik")
                (. (addTo m)))
            (-> [-37.9 144.8]
                L.marker
                (. (addTo m))
                (. (bindPopup "<i style='color:purple'>Have you been here?</i>"))
                (. (openPopup)))))]]
 {:html/deps [:leaflet]
  :style {:height "400px"}})
